Both are still NBA calibre players easily imo in terms of skill but their character is just too tough to deal with along with questionable work ethic. Especially Beasley at times looked like the greatest player in the NBA when he decided to go all out and have a good day at the same time.  Currently in the league I'd say Lonzo Ball, Andrew Wiggins. And a guy that was a Superstar but still never quite reached his peak would be Blake Griffin. Injuries once again held him back from having his best season. > How do you differentiate that situation from bad organizations where a player just happened to develop?  Why is it that, year after year, the worst teams get the best draft picks, and, year after year, the worst teams draft mostly busts with those best draft picks? But don't stick too hard to one team at the start, you'll find what you like over time   >Is youth development different in the NBA in comparison to hockey and soccer?  Very. In the NBA teams have nothing to do with the players basically until they are drafted.    >Do players that get drafted in round 1 make the roster right away, or do they play in college for 4 years and then compete for a roster spot or play on the farm team  If you're a 1st round pick your contract is already guaranteed, so the team is gonna be paying you no matter what, so they pretty much all play on the team for at least a bit. Some of them won't last on their teams and in the league, but the guys at the top all generally do. The 2nd round is a different story, their contracts aren't guaranteed and the majority of them never make their teams roster and they never play in the NBA.   Players never draft someone and have them go to college, you'll kind of see it with Europeans who get drafted by a team but stay and play in Europe, but never still going to college. To be drafted players also have to be a year removed from highschool, which usually means playing a year in college before heading to the NBA.   > I understand drafts are essential but do picks have very high value or do teams just trade them continually?  Picks have a high value, but it's a pretty steep value curve, the ones at the top are worth much more than ones later on. How this value works out depends on the draft and how many good players there are. A top 3 pick in a good draft can be worth five times a pick at 12. Teams do trade picks a lot, usually as a move to help them win now at the expense of success in the future. As such most of the picks that get traded are from good teams that are expecting their picks to not be very high anyway (examples like the Nets, Lakers, Bucks), but sometimes doesn't work out and not very good teams owe picks (Rockets, TWolves, the Nets of the past).     >Are there lots of young players that get drafted later rounds that actually make it to the NBA rosters or do they get trapped on the farm team and used as trade bait/salary moves?   It's pretty common for 2nd round draft picks to make it onto NBA teams. It's less than half, especially as you get to the end of the draft, but not insignificant each draft. There's also stars that every once in a while come from the 2nd round, Jokic is currently an MVP candidate and he was the 41st pick. I wouldn't say they get trapped on the farm team (in the NBA this is called the G-League), but it's pretty common for them to be sent down to get reps. You will see 2nd round picks and players moved pretty often, they aren't seen to carry a lot of value, but they are probably the cheapest asset that is still positive value.   >Do top picks bust frequently, as a Canadian, I do know that the hype on Wiggins and Bennett completely died out after 1 year. I haven't kept a close eye on them but it seems that they couldn't transition their game/skills to an NBA starter level?  I wouldn't say frequently, but it definitely ain't unheard of. I think failing to make it to the level of a starter is rarer (Wiggins is actually a starter), but it's pretty common to not meet expectations.   In 2018 Marvin Bagley with the 2nd pick and probably won't be a good player, Markelle Fultz in 2017 was the 1st pick but immediately disappointed and is now just a good player, Dragan Bender in 2016 with the 4th pick is already out of the league. There seems to be at least one high level prospect per draft who doesn't get near their expectations.   >I watch hockey and soccer, but the Salary Cap and contract situation in the NBA is much different, based on my understanding, it seems to promote rich owners to throw money and build super teams, so does it make the NBA a bit stale to watch?  There is a salary cap in the NBA, it's just a soft cap, and there is also a cap on the salaries of players. So you can go over the cap, but there are a bunch of restrictions to limit your ability to do so, primarily you can go over the cap to sign players that are already on your team, but you can't go over the cap to get other teams players. However, going over the cap does lead to you ending up in the luxury tax, which the more you go into the more expensive it gets  There's still a big market advantage, but it's to varying degrees. My Nets were able to sign Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving in free agency because they are located in New York, but also because they have shown themselves to be a competent franchise who can get some modicum of success. While across the city the Knicks are the most valuable franchise in the NBA, and they haven't been able to get a free agent in close to 10 years because they are so bad. So rich owners (so long as they aren't cheap) have less impact, but the markets teams are in have an impact. The big exception to this I would say is the Lakers, who I think has just a massive free-agent advantage over other teams  On the other hand, some small-market teams are able to hold onto really high-level players over the long term. As I said before there is a player salary cap, where players can only be paid so much. But this quantity is affected by a range of things, firstly how long a player has been in the league, secondly if a player signs with their own team then they can get more and for longer, and thirdly if they are eligible for getting the supermax, which you have to reach certain performance levels for and you can only get re-signing with your team. Protections vary depending on the terms of the trade, and they're evaluated after the lottery takes place. [This massive page](https://basketball.realgm.com/nba/draft/future_drafts/detailed) can help you figure out the details of specific picks.   If you scroll down to Houston and look at the first item in the outgoing column, the situation for the pick in question is there.  >  **2021 first round draft pick to Oklahoma City (swap, less favorable of Oklahoma City or Miami incoming)** Oklahoma City will receive the two most favorable of its 2021 1st round pick, Miami's 2021 1st round pick and Houston's 2021 1st round pick protected for selections 1-4 and Houston will receive the least favorable of the three (via Miami to Phoenix to Philadelphia to L.A. Clippers to Oklahoma City; via Oklahoma City's right to swap Oklahoma City or Miami for Houston); **if the Houston pick falls within its protected range and is therefore not conveyable, then Houston's obligation to Oklahoma City will be extinguished** and Oklahoma City will instead receive its pick and the Miami pick [Miami-New Orleans-Phoenix, 2/19/2015; Philadelphia-Phoenix, 6/21/2018; L.A. Clippers-Philadelphia, 2/6/2019; L.A. Clippers-Oklahoma City, 7/10/2019; Houston-Oklahoma City, 7/16/2019]; Houston may convey this pick to Brooklyn in 2021 (see Houston Incoming)  So if they do get pick 1, 2, 3, or 4 in the lottery, they don't have to give OKC anything in return. There's only a 52.1% chance of that happening.  That's not always the norm. A lot of trades will have some sort of caveat where if a protected pick doesn't convey one year, then the next year's pick is owed (sometimes with looser protections). But pick swaps (which I think this is) seem to be options that apply only to a single year at a time.   Random history example: The Kings once traded away a 1st round pick that was protected top 14 the first year, top 13 the next, then top 12, then top 10 for the next 3 years, and then became a 2nd round pick after they failed so many years in a row to win enough games to convey the pick. That final year, the Kings pick that they kept jumped in the lottery to #3 and swapped with Philly down to #5 due to a different trade. Philly traded the #3 pick to Boston to get #1 and draft Markelle Fultz. Boston used the #3 pick on Jayson Tatum. The Kings used the #5 pick on DeAaron Fox. The second round pick conveyed instead went to Chicago, who eventually sold it to the Warriors, who drafted Jordan Bell with it.

It's fundamental to how this whole process works. A person having a high PER or WARP isn't what causes the basketball to go in the hoop. Physical processes, decisions and interactions do and you then find the number afterward.   So while looking backward from a high PER means that likely the physical processes and decisions are there that would cause the ball to go in the hoop for their team (and not for the other team) more often when they're on the floor, which would cause the player's PER to be high, those physical processes can change in ways that PER won't reflect, like Markelle Fultz injuring his shoulder or Vince Carter, James Harden or Anthony Davis getting into a feud with their teams.  Since we don't have concrete ways to reflect those physical things, the correlations, as they always do, will be good most of the time and miss massively some of the time. Which is a minefield when it comes to relying on the models.
